SecureFedYJ: a safe feature Gaussianization protocol for Federated Learning

Tanguy Marchand
Owkin Inc., New York, USA.
tanguy.marchand@owkin.com &Boris Muzellec

boris.muzellec@owkin.com Constance Beguier

Abstract

The Yeo-Johnson (YJ) transformation is a standard parametrized per-feature unidimensional transformation often used to Gaussianize features in machine learning. In this paper, we investigate the problem of applying the YJ transformation in a cross-silo Federated Learning setting under privacy constraints. For the first time, we prove that the YJ negative log-likelihood is in fact convex, which allows us to optimize it with exponential search. We numerically show that the resulting algorithm is more stable than the state-of-the-art approach based on the Brent minimization method. Building on this simple algorithm and Secure Multiparty Computation routines, we propose SecureFedYJ, a federated algorithm that performs a pooled-equivalent YJ transformation without leaking more information than the final fitted parameters do. Quantitative experiments on real data demonstrate that, in addition to being secure, our approach reliably normalizes features across silos as well as if data were pooled, making it a viable approach for safe federated feature Gaussianization.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) [45, 32] is an approach that was recently proposed to train machine learning (ML) models across multiple data holders, or clients, without centralizing data points, notably for privacy reasons. While many FL applications have been proposed, two main settings have emerged [23]: cross-device FL, involving a large number of small edge devices, and cross-silo FL, dealing with a smaller number of clients, with larger computational capabilities. Due to the sensitivity and relative local scarcity of medical data, healthcare is a promising application of cross-silo FL [40], e.g. to train a biomedical ML model between different hospitals as if all the datasets were pooled in a central server. In this paper, we focus on the cross-silo setting.

The constraints of cross-silo FL

Although cross-silo FL resembles standard distributed learning, it faces at least two important distinct challenges: privacy and heterogeneity. Due to data sensitivity, clients might impose stringent security and privacy constraints on FL collaborations. This arises in coopetitive FL projects, where models are jointly trained on industrial competitors’ datasets [55], as well as medical FL applications, where conservative data regulations might apply. In this setting, using standard FL algorithms such as FedAvg [32] might not provide enough privacy guarantees, as privacy attacks such as data reconstruction can be carried out based on the clients’ gradients [56, 54]. Various protocols based on Secure Multiparty Computation (SMC) (see Section 2 for more details), such as Secure Aggregation [4], can mitigate this shortcoming by disclosing only the sum of the gradients from all clients to the server, without disclosing each gradient individually.

An additional constraint is that data might present statistical heterogeneity across clients, i.e. the local clients’ data distributions may not be identical. In the case of medical applications, such heterogeneity may be caused e.g. by environmental variations or differences in the material that was used for acquisition [43, 47, 2]. While different ways of adapting federated training algorithms have been proposed to automatically tackle heterogeneity [28, 29, 24], these solutions do not address data harmonization and normalization prior to FL training.

Preprocessing in ML

Data preprocessing is a crucial step in many ML applications, leading to important performance gains. Among others, common preprocessing methods include data whitening, principal component analysis (PCA) [22] or zero component analysis [27, 20, 46]. However, linear normalization methods might not suffice when the original data distribution is highly non-Gaussian. For tabular and time series data, a popular approach to Gaussianize the marginal distributions is to apply feature-wise non-linear transformations. Two commonly-used parametric methods are the Box-Cox [5] transformation and its extension, the Yeo-Johnson (YJ) transformation [52]. Both have been used in multiple applications, such as climate and weather forecast [53, 50, 51], economics [13] and genomic studies [7, 58, 9].

Problem and contributions

In this paper, we investigate the problem of data normalization in the cross-silo FL setting, by exploring how to apply the YJ transformation to a distributed dataset. This problem arises frequently in medical cross-silo FL, e.g. when trying to jointly train models on genetic data (see e.g. [19, 57]). Due to data heterogeneity, no single client can act as a reference client: indeed, there is no guarantee that transformation parameters fitted on a single client would be relevant for other clients’ data. Hence, it is necessary to fit normalization methods on the full federated dataset. Moreover, in this setting, data privacy is of paramount importance, and therefore FL protocols should be carefully designed. Our main contributions to this problem are as follows:

  1. 1.

    We prove that the negative YJ log-likelihood is convex (Section 3), which is a novel result, to the best of our knowledge.

  2. 2.

    Building on this property, we introduce ExpYJ, a method to fit the YJ transformation based on exponential search (Section 3). We numerically show that this method is more stable than standard approaches for fitting the YJ transformation based on the Brent minimization method [6].

  3. 3.

    We propose SecureFedYJ (Section 4), a secure way to extend ExpYJ in the cross-silo FL setting using SMC. We show that SecureFedYJ does not leak any information on the datasets apart from what is leaked by the parameters minimizing the YJ negative log-likelihood (Section 4 and Proposition 4.1). By construction, SecureFedYJ provides the same results as the pooled-equivalent ExpYJ, regardless of how the data is split across the clients. We check this property in numerical experiments (Section 4). The core ideas behind the resulting algorithm, SecureFedYJ, are summarised in Figure 7.

Finally, we illustrate our contributions in numerical applications on synthetic and genomic data in Section 5.

2 Background

The Yeo-Johnson transformation

The YJ transformation [52] was introduced in order to Gaussianize data that can be either positive or negative. It was proposed as a generalization of the Box-Cox transformation [5], that only applies to non-negative data. The YJ transformation consists in applying to each feature a monotonic function Ψ​(λ,⋅)Ψ𝜆⋅\Psi(\lambda,\cdot) parametrized by a scalar λ𝜆\lambda, independently of the other features. Thus, there are as many λ𝜆\lambda’s as there are features. For a real number x𝑥x, Ψ​(λ,x)Ψ𝜆𝑥\Psi(\lambda,x) is defined as:

Ψ​(λ,x)={[(x+1)λ−1]/λ,if ​x≥0,λ≠0,ln⁡(x+1),if ​x≥0,λ=0,−[(−x+1)2−λ−1]/(2−λ),if ​x<0,λ≠2,−ln⁡(−x+1),if ​x<0,λ=2.Ψ𝜆𝑥casesdelimited-[]superscript𝑥1𝜆1𝜆formulae-sequenceif 𝑥0𝜆0𝑥1formulae-sequenceif 𝑥0𝜆0delimited-[]superscript𝑥12𝜆12𝜆formulae-sequenceif 𝑥0𝜆2𝑥1formulae-sequenceif 𝑥0𝜆2\Psi(\lambda,x)=\begin{cases}[(x+1)^{\lambda}-1]/\lambda,&\text{if }x\geq 0,\lambda\neq 0,\\ \ln(x+1),&\text{if }x\geq 0,\lambda=0,\\ -[(-x+1)^{2-\lambda}-1]/(2-\lambda),&\text{if }x<0,\lambda\neq 2,\\ -\ln(-x+1),&\text{if }x<0,\lambda=2.\\ \end{cases} (1)

Figure 1(a) shows the shape of the YJ function for various values of λ𝜆\lambda.

The Yeo-Johnson likelihood

Let us consider real-valued samples {xi}i=1,⋯,nsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1⋯𝑛\{x_{i}\}_{i=1,\cdots,n}, and let us apply the YJ transformation Ψ​(λ,⋅)Ψ𝜆⋅\Psi(\lambda,\cdot) to these samples to Gaussianize their distribution. The log-likelihood that {Ψ​(λ,xi)}i=1,⋯,nsubscriptΨ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1⋯𝑛\{\Psi(\lambda,x_{i})\}_{i=1,\cdots,n} comes from a Gaussian with mean μ𝜇\mu and variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is given by (derivation details are provided in Section A.1):

log⁡ℒYJ​(λ,σ2,μ)=−n2​log⁡(2​π​σ2)−12​σ2​∑i=1n[Ψ​(λ,xi)−μ]2+(λ−1)​∑i=1nsgn⁡(xi)​log⁡(|xi|+1).subscriptℒYJ𝜆superscript𝜎2𝜇𝑛22𝜋superscript𝜎212superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptdelimited-[]Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖𝜇2𝜆1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛sgnsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}(\lambda,\sigma^{2},\mu)=-\frac{n}{2}\log(2\pi\sigma^{2})-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[\Psi(\lambda,x_{i})-\mu\right]^{2}+(\lambda-1)\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{sgn}(x_{i})\log(|x_{i}|+1). (2)

For a given λ𝜆\lambda, the log-likelihood is maximized for μ∗=1n​∑i=1nΨ​(λ,xi)subscript𝜇1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖\mu_{*}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Psi(\lambda,x_{i}) and σ∗2=1n​∑i=1n(Ψ​(xi,λ)−μ∗)2subscriptsuperscript𝜎21𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptΨsubscript𝑥𝑖𝜆subscript𝜇2\sigma^{2}_{*}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\Psi(x_{i},\lambda)-\mu_{*})^{2}. Once we replace μ𝜇\mu and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} by μ∗subscript𝜇\mu_{*} and σ∗2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}_{*}, it becomes:

log⁡ℒYJ​(λ)=−n2​log⁡(σΨ​(λ,{xi})2)+(λ−1)​∑i=1nsgn⁡(xi)​log⁡(|xi|+1)−n2​log⁡(2​π),subscriptℒYJ𝜆𝑛2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛sgnsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1𝑛22𝜋\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}(\lambda)=-\frac{n}{2}\log(\sigma^{2}_{\Psi(\lambda,\{x_{i}\})})+(\lambda-1)\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{sgn}(x_{i})\log(|x_{i}|+1)-\frac{n}{2}\log(2\pi), (3)

see  [52]. Maximizing the YJ log-likelihood is therefore a 1-dimensional problem for each feature. Once the optimal λ∗subscript𝜆\lambda_{*} is found, the transformed data Ψ​(λ,xi)Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖\Psi(\lambda,x_{i}) is usually renormalized by subtracting its empirical mean μ∗subscript𝜇\mu_{*} and dividing by the square root of its empirical variance σ∗2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}_{*}. Figure 1(b) shows an example of the YJ transformation applied to a skew-normal distribution.

Note that in a typical application, the triplet (λ∗,μ∗,σ∗2)subscript𝜆subscript𝜇subscriptsuperscript𝜎2(\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma^{2}_{*}) is fitted on the training data only, and is then used to Gaussianize the test dataset during inference.

Minimization methods in dimension 1

As seen above, fitting a YJ transformation can be reduced to a 1D optimization problem. To tackle this problem, we introduce two standard 1D minimization methods: (i) Brent minimization [6] and (ii) exponential search [3].

Brent minimization [6] (not to be confused with the Brent-Dekker method, see [6], chapters 3 and 4) is a widely used method for 1D optimization. It is based on golden section search and successive parabolic interpolations, and does not require evaluating any derivatives. This algorithm is guaranteed to converge to a local minimum with superlinear convergence of order at least 1.3247. Standard implementations of the YJ transformation, in particular the scikit-learn implementation [36], are based on the Brent minimization method to minimize the negative log-likelihood provided by Eq. (3).

Exponential search [3] is a dichotomic algorithm designed for unbounded search spaces. The idea is to first find bounds, and then to perform a classic binary search within these bounds. This algorithm can be used to find the minimum of convex differentiable functions with linear convergence, as explained in Appendix B. In this work, we build on exponential search to propose a federated version of the YJ transform, for two main reasons: (i) it is more numerically stable than Brent minimization, as shown in Section 3 and Figure 2, (ii), it may conveniently be adapted to a federated setting, as shown in Section 4, and (iii), this latter federated adaptation offers strong privacy garantees, as shown by Proposition 4.1.

Secure Multiparty Computation

As illustrated by various privacy gradient attacks [56, 54], sensitive information on the clients’ datasets can be leaked to the central server during an FL training. One way to mitigate this risk is to use Secure Multiparty Computation (SMC) protocols to hide individual contributions to the server. SMC enables one to evaluate functions with inputs distributed across different users without revealing intermediate results and is often based on secret sharing. SMC protocols tailored for ML use-cases have been recently proposed [12, 14, 34, 39, 48, 33, 49, 41]. These protocols are either designed to enhance the privacy of FL trainings, or to perform secure inference, i.e. to enable the evaluation of model trained privately on a server without revealing the data nor the model.

A popular FL algorithm relying on SMC is Secure Aggregation (SA) [4]. Schematically, in SA each client adds a random mask to their model update before sending it to the central server. These masks have been tailored in such a way that they all together sum to zero. Therefore, the central server cannot see the individual updates of the clients, but it can recover the sum of these updates by adding all the masked quantities sent from them.

More generally, an SMC routine schematically works as follows (we refer to Appendix D for further details). Let us consider the setting where K𝐾K parties k=1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k=1,\dots,K want to compute g=f​(h(1),…,h(K))𝑔𝑓superscriptℎ1…superscriptℎ𝐾g=f(h^{(1)},\dots,h^{(K)}) for a known function f𝑓f, where (h(1),…,h(K))superscriptℎ1…superscriptℎ𝐾(h^{(1)},\dots,h^{(K)}) denote private inputs. Each party k𝑘k knows h(k)superscriptℎ𝑘h^{(k)} and is not willing to share it. During the first step, secret sharing, each party splits its private input h(k)superscriptℎ𝑘h^{(k)} into K secret shares h1(k),…,hK(k)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑘1…subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑘𝐾h^{(k)}_{1},\dots,h^{(k)}_{K}, and sends the shares hk′(k)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑘superscript𝑘′h^{(k)}_{k^{\prime}} to the party k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime}. These secret shares are constructed in such a way that (i) knowing hk′(k)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑘superscript𝑘′h^{(k)}_{k^{\prime}} does not provide any information on the value of h(k)superscriptℎ𝑘h^{(k)}, and (ii) h(k)superscriptℎ𝑘h^{(k)} can be reconstructed from the vector (h1(k),…,hK(k))subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑘1…subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑘𝐾(h^{(k)}_{1},\dots,h^{(k)}_{K}). For simplicity, we denote ⟦h(k)⟧=(h1(k),…,hK(k))\llbracket h^{(k)}\rrbracket=(h^{(k)}_{1},\dots,h^{(k)}_{K}) the vector of share secrets. In a second step, the computation, each party k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime} computes the quantity denoted gk′subscript𝑔superscript𝑘′g_{k^{\prime}} using the secret shares they know along with intermediate quantities exchanged with the other parties. The way to compute gk′subscript𝑔superscript𝑘′g_{k^{\prime}} depends on f𝑓f and on the SMC protocol that is used, and is chosen so that g=f​(h(1),…,h(K))𝑔𝑓superscriptℎ1…superscriptℎ𝐾g=f(h^{(1)},\dots,h^{(K)}) can be reconstructed from (g1,…​gK)subscript𝑔1…subscript𝑔𝐾(g_{1},\dots g_{K}). Said otherwise, gk′subscript𝑔superscript𝑘′g_{k^{\prime}} are secret shares of g𝑔g: ⟦g⟧=(g1,…gK)\llbracket g\rrbracket=(g_{1},\dots g_{K}). Finally, during the reveal step, each party k𝑘k reveals gksubscript𝑔𝑘g_{k} to all other parties, and each party can reconstruct g𝑔g from (g1,…​gK)subscript𝑔1…subscript𝑔𝐾(g_{1},\dots g_{K}).

Threat model

In this work, we consider an honest-but-curious setting [35]. Neither the clients nor the server will deviate from the agreed protocol, but each party can potentially try to infer as much information as possible using data they see during the protocol. This setting is relevant for cross-silo FL, where participants are often large institutions whose reputation could be ternished by a more malicious behaviour.

3 A novel method to optimize the Yeo-Johnson log-likelihood: ExpYJ 

In this section, we leverage the convexity of the negative log-likelihood of the YJ transformation (see Proposition 3.1) to propose a new method to find the optimal λ∗subscript𝜆\lambda_{*} using exponential search. While this method only offers linear convergence, compared to the super-linear convergence of Brent minimization method, we demonstrate two of its advantages: (i) it is more numerically stable, and (ii) it is easily amenable to an FL setting with strong privacy guarantees. The method proposed in this section is based on the following result.

Proposition 3.1.

The negative log-likehood λ↦−log⁡ℒYJ​(λ)maps-to𝜆subscriptℒYJ𝜆\lambda\mapsto-\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}(\lambda) (3) is strictly convex.

The proof of Proposition 3.1 builds upon the work of [26] which shows that the negative log-likelihood of the Box-Cox transformation [5] is convex. The complete proof is deferred to Appendix C.

The exponential YJ algorithm

The pseudo-code of the proposed algorithm is presented in Algorithm 1, and relies on the exponential search presented in Algorithm 2 (cf Appendix B for more details on exponential search). An illustration of ExpYJ is shown in Figure 6 in Appendix B. Due to the strict convexity of the negative log-likelihood of the YJ transformation, we may perform the exponential search described in Section 2 and Appendix B. To do so, it is enough to obtain the sign of the derivative. Let ∂λΨ​(λ,⋅)2=2​Ψ​(λ,⋅)​∂λΨ​(λ,⋅)subscript𝜆Ψsuperscript𝜆⋅22Ψ𝜆⋅subscript𝜆Ψ𝜆⋅\partial_{\lambda}\Psi(\lambda,\cdot)^{2}=2\Psi(\lambda,\cdot)\partial_{\lambda}\Psi(\lambda,\cdot) and φ​(x)=sgn⁡(x)+log⁡(|x|+1).𝜑𝑥sgn𝑥𝑥1\varphi(x)=\operatorname{sgn}(x)+\log(|x|+1). Further, for g∈{Ψ​(λ,⋅),∂λΨ​(λ,⋅),Ψ​(λ,⋅)2,∂λΨ​(λ,⋅)2,φ}𝑔Ψ𝜆⋅subscript𝜆Ψ𝜆⋅Ψsuperscript𝜆⋅2subscript𝜆Ψsuperscript𝜆⋅2𝜑g\in\{\Psi(\lambda,\cdot),\partial_{\lambda}\Psi(\lambda,\cdot),\Psi(\lambda,\cdot)^{2},\partial_{\lambda}\Psi(\lambda,\cdot)^{2},\varphi\}, let us define Sg=def∑i=1ng​(xi).superscriptdefsubscript𝑆𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑔subscript𝑥𝑖S_{g}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}g(x_{i}). The derivative of the log-likelihood is available in closed form (see Section A.3):

∂λlog⁡ℒYJ=n2​S∂Ψ2−2​(SΨ​S∂Ψ)/nSΨ2−SΨ2/n−Sφ.subscript𝜆subscriptℒYJ𝑛2subscript𝑆superscriptΨ22subscript𝑆Ψsubscript𝑆Ψ𝑛subscript𝑆superscriptΨ2subscriptsuperscript𝑆2Ψ𝑛subscript𝑆𝜑\partial_{\lambda}\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}=\frac{n}{2}\frac{S_{\partial\Psi^{2}}-2(S_{\Psi}S_{\partial\Psi})/n}{S_{\Psi^{2}}-S^{2}_{\Psi}/n}-S_{\varphi}. Notice that SΨ2−SΨ2/nsubscript𝑆superscriptΨ2subscriptsuperscript𝑆2Ψ𝑛S_{\Psi^{2}}-S^{2}_{\Psi}/n can be expressed as a variance, hence is non-negative. (5)

Avoiding this division is crucial to make the overall procedure more numerical stable, as explained below, and eases the use of SMC routines.

Accuracy of ExpYJ

We check the accuracy of ExpYJ on the datasets presented in Section E.1. In particular, we compare the results provided by ExpYJ with the outputs of the scikit-learn algorithm based on Brent minimization.

For 2 of the 108 features present in the datasets, the scikit-learn implementation leads to numerical instabilities discussed hereafter. Therefore, we focus our comparison on the 106 remaining features, that we aggregated regardless of the dataset. Figure 2 reports the relative difference δ​λ𝛿𝜆\delta\lambda between the results obtained by ExpYJ and by the scikit-learn implementation as a function of the number of iteration tmaxsubscript𝑡maxt_{\mathrm{max}} (as defined in Algorithm 1). These results show that this relative difference is of order less than  10−6superscript10610^{-6} when tmax=40subscript𝑡max40t_{\mathrm{max}}=40.

Numerical stability of ExpYJ

Our experiments demonstrate that ExpYJ is numerically more stable than Brent minimization. Indeed, for some values of λ𝜆\lambda and some datasets {xi}subscript𝑥𝑖\{x_{i}\}, the transformation Ψ​(λ,⋅)Ψ𝜆⋅\Psi(\lambda,\cdot) concentrates all data points in a small interval such that the values of Ψ​(λ,{xi})Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖\Psi(\lambda,\{x_{i}\}) are all equal up to machine precision. In that case, the log-likelihood is not well-defined and the term log⁡σΨλ2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscriptΨ𝜆\log\sigma^{2}_{\Psi_{\lambda}} takes the value −∞-\infty, which prevents Brent minimization from converging. This phenomenon does not affect the ExpYJ routine as we do not compute directly the sign of ∂λℒ=∂λσΨλ2/σΨλ2−∑iφ​(xi)subscript𝜆ℒsubscript𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscriptΨ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscriptΨ𝜆subscript𝑖𝜑subscript𝑥𝑖\partial_{\lambda}\mathcal{L}=\partial_{\lambda}\sigma^{2}_{\Psi_{\lambda}}/\sigma^{2}_{\Psi_{\lambda}}-\sum_{i}\varphi(x_{i}), but rather the sign of σΨλ2​∂λℒ=−∂λσΨλ2−σΨλ2​∑iφ​(xi)subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscriptΨ𝜆subscript𝜆ℒsubscript𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscriptΨ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscriptΨ𝜆subscript𝑖𝜑subscript𝑥𝑖\sigma^{2}_{\Psi_{\lambda}}\partial_{\lambda}\mathcal{L}=-\partial_{\lambda}\sigma^{2}_{\Psi_{\lambda}}-\sigma^{2}_{\Psi_{\lambda}}\sum_{i}\varphi(x_{i}), see Eq. (5).

Figure 2 illustrates this in the case of a feature of the Breast Cancer Dataset. The λ∗subscript𝜆\lambda_{*} returned by the Brent minimization method of scikit-learn is −14.5314.53-14.53 while the minimizer of the negative log-likelihood found by the ExpYJ is −0.210.21-0.21. In particular, Figure 2 shows the values of the negative log-likelihood as a function of λ𝜆\lambda computed using 64-bit float precision. The orange vertical full bands correspond to values for which σΨλ2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscriptΨ𝜆2\sigma_{\Psi_{\lambda}}^{2} is zero within the machine precision, resulting to a negative log-likelihood of ∞\infty. This instability happens for 2 of the 108 features used in numerical experiments, where blindly applying the Brent-based YJ transformation leads to all data points collapsing to zero, while ExpYJ succeeds in transforming the data distributions to more Gaussian-like ones. Section E.4 shows that this issue also arises in other real-life datasets.

4 Applying the Yeo-Johnson transformation in FL

So far, we only considered the centralized setting, where data is accessible from a single server. Yet, as mentioned in Sections 1 and 2, many real-world situations require working with heterogeneous data split between different centers, and to take privacy constraints into account. When the data is split across centers k=1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k=1,\dots,K and the function to optimize is separable, i.e. of the form ℱ​(λ)=∑k=1Kfk​(λ)ℱ𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑓𝑘𝜆\mathcal{F}(\lambda)=\sum_{k=1}^{K}f_{k}(\lambda) where each fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} can be computed from data present in the center k𝑘k exclusively, Federated Learning techniques were recently proposed. In short, they consist in repeatedly performing a few rounds of local optimization in each center, before aggregating local parameters in the server. We refer to [23] for an overview of recent advances in FL. In our case, however, the YJ negative log-likelihood (3) is not separable, due to the log-variance term. Indeed, turning the variance into a separable term would require sharing the global YJ mean μλsubscript𝜇𝜆\mu_{\lambda} to all centers at each iteration. Compared to the method we propose in this section, this would lead to more privacy leakage.

We now introduce SecureFedYJ, a secure federated algorithm that builds upon ExpYJ to apply YJ transformations. This algorithm satisfies the two following properties: (i) it is pooled-equivalent, i.e. it yields the same results as if the data were freely accessible from a single server, and (ii) it leaks as little information as possible about the underlying datasets, as shown by Proposition 4.1. Finally, it converges in a limited number of iterations, thanks to the linear convergence of the underlying exponential search.

SecureFedYJ

SecureFedYJ is a federated adaptation of ExpYJ presented in Section 3 to find the best parameters (λ∗,μ∗,σ∗2)subscript𝜆subscript𝜇superscriptsubscript𝜎2(\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma_{*}^{2}) of the YJ transformation when training datasets are split across different clients. It relies on SMC to ensure that only the final triplet (λ∗,μ∗,σ∗2)subscript𝜆subscript𝜇superscriptsubscript𝜎2(\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma_{*}^{2}) fitted on the training datasets is revealed, without leaking any other information apart from the overall total number of training samples n𝑛n. Indeed, at each intermediate step, only the sign of ∂λlog⁡ℒYJsubscript𝜆subscriptℒYJ\partial_{\lambda}\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}} is revealed, and the mean and variance of the transformed data is only revealed at the last step. The pseudo-code of the resulting algorithm is presented in Algorithm 3, and relies on the exponential search presented in Algorithm 2. A functional representation of SecureFedYJ is displayed Figure 7.

In Algorithm 3,we label the clients by k=1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k=1,\dots,K and each client k𝑘k holds data {xk,i:i=1,…,nk}conditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖𝑖1…subscript𝑛𝑘\{x_{k,i}:i=1,\dots,n_{k}\}. We suppose that the total number of samples n=∑k=1Knk𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑛𝑘n=\sum_{k=1}^{K}n_{k} is public and shared to all clients. For a given function g𝑔g, we denote Sk,gsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑔S_{k,g} the sum Sk,g=def∑i=1nkg​(xk,i).superscriptdefsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑘𝑔subscript𝑥𝑘𝑖S_{k,g}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{k}}g(x_{k,i}). As introduced in Section 2, we use double brackets ⟦⋅⟧delimited-⟦⟧⋅\llbracket\cdot\rrbracket to indicate an SMC secret shared across the clients (see Appendix D for more details).

Privacy leakage

In Proposition 4.1 we show that Algorithm 3 only reveals information already contained in the fitted triplet (λ∗,μ∗,σ∗2)subscript𝜆subscript𝜇superscriptsubscript𝜎2(\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma_{*}^{2}). In comparison, turning the YJ negative log-likelihood (3) into a log-separable function before using off-the-shelf FL methods would require sharing μ𝜇\mu and its gradient and centrally computing σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} for intermediate values of λ𝜆\lambda at each iteration. This could potentially lead to uncontrolled privacy leakage.

Proposition 4.1.

The fitted parameter λ∗subscript𝜆\lambda_{*} contains all the information revealed during the intermediate steps of SecureFedYJ. More precisely, there exists a deterministic function ℱℱ\mathcal{F} such that for any set of datasets {xk,i}subscript𝑥𝑘𝑖\{x_{k,i}\} , if λ∗​({xk,i})subscript𝜆subscript𝑥𝑘𝑖\lambda_{*}(\{x_{k,i}\}) is the result of SecureFedYJ on {xk,i}subscript𝑥𝑘𝑖\{x_{k,i}\}, then {λt,λt+,λt−,Δt}t=1,⋯,tmax=ℱ​[λ∗​({xk,i})]subscriptsubscript𝜆𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡subscriptΔ𝑡𝑡1⋯subscript𝑡maxℱdelimited-[]subscript𝜆subscript𝑥𝑘𝑖\{\lambda_{t},\lambda^{+}_{t},\lambda^{-}_{t},\Delta_{t}\}_{t=1,\cdots,t_{\mathrm{max}}}=\mathcal{F}\left[\lambda_{*}(\{x_{k,i}\})\right]

Proof. This proposition comes from the fact that all gradient signs ΔtsubscriptΔ𝑡\Delta_{t} revealed during the algorithm can be retrospectively inferred from λ∗subscript𝜆\lambda_{*}. Indeed, ∂λlog⁡ℒYJ<0subscript𝜆subscriptℒYJ0\partial_{\lambda}\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}<0 for λ>λ∗𝜆subscript𝜆\lambda>\lambda_{*} and ∂λlog⁡ℒYJ>0subscript𝜆subscriptℒYJ0\partial_{\lambda}\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}>0 for λ<λ∗𝜆subscript𝜆\lambda<\lambda_{*}. Besides, the successive values of λtsubscript𝜆𝑡\lambda_{t} explored at each step t𝑡t can be deterministically inferred from the initial value λt=0subscript𝜆𝑡0\lambda_{t=0} and and the final fitted value λ∗subscript𝜆\lambda_{*}. We construct such a function ℱℱ\mathcal{F} and numerical verify this proposition in Appendix F. ■■\blacksquare

Performance of SecureFedYJ

We implement SecureFedYJ in Python, using the MPyC library [42] based on Shamir Secret Sharing [44]. We refer to Appendix D for more details on our implementation. To represent signed real-valued numbers in an SMC protocol, we use a fixed-point representation (see Section D.2) using l𝑙l bits, among which f𝑓f bits are used for the decimal parts. This means that we consider floats ranging from −2l−fsuperscript2𝑙𝑓-2^{l-f} to 2l−fsuperscript2𝑙𝑓2^{l-f} and that we have an absolution precision of 2−fsuperscript2𝑓2^{-f} in our computations.

In order to ensure the accuracy of SecureFedYJ results, we need to make sure that l𝑙l and f𝑓f are large enough. Figure 3 shows the accuracy of SecureFedYJ when compared to ExpYJ for various values of f𝑓f. According to these numerical experiments, taking f=50𝑓50f=50 and l=100𝑙100l=100 provides reasonably accurate results. Moreover, by construction, the outputs of SecureFedYJ do not depend on how the data is split across the clients, up to rounding numerical errors. Therefore this algorithm is resilient to data heterogeneity, as long as the numerical decimal precision f𝑓f is large enough, as shown in Figure 3.

Performing SecureFedYJ with tmax=40subscript𝑡40t_{\mathrm{\max}}=40 takes 726 rounds of communication (see Section D.6). During these communication rounds, each client sends overall about 8 Mb per feature to every other client (see also Section D.6). SecureFedYJ can be applied independently and in parallel to each feature. Therefore, the overall number of rounds does not depend on the number of features being considered, and the communication costs grow proportionally to the number of features. In a realistic cross-silo FL setting as described in [19], the bandwidth of the network is 111 Gb per second with a delay of 20​ms20ms20\ \mathrm{ms} between every two clients. In this context, the execution of SecureFedYJ with tmax=40subscript𝑡40t_{\mathrm{\max}}=40 on p𝑝p features would take about 726×20​ms≃15​ssimilar-to-or-equals72620ms15s726\times 20\ \mathrm{ms}\simeq 15\ \mathrm{s} due to the communication overhead, in addition to p×8​Mb/1​Gbps≃8​p​mssimilar-to-or-equals𝑝8Mb1Gbps8𝑝msp\times 8\ \mathrm{Mb}/1\ \mathrm{Gbps}\simeq 8p\ \mathrm{ms} due to the bandwidth. This shows that SecureFedYJ is indeed a viable algorithm in a real-world scenario.

As pointed out in Appendix B, the binary search in the exponential search can be replaced by a k𝑘k-ary search. In such a setting, the sign of the negative log-likelihood of the YJ transformation is computed for k−1𝑘1k-1 different values of λ𝜆\lambda at each round. Such a modification would reduce the number of communication rounds required to obtain a given accuracy, while increasing the size of the data exchanged over the network at each round.

5 Applications

Genomic data: TCGA

We start by showing the benefits of YJ preprocessing in survival analysis experiments on lung (LUAD+LUSC), pancreas (PAAD), and colorectal (CRC) cancers. Given gene expression raw counts (features) and censored survival data (responses) from patients having either of those three cancers, we aim to fit a Cox Proportional Hazards (CoxPH) model [10] with the highest possible concordance index (C-index) [25], which measures how well patients are ranked with respect to their survival times. We refer to [25] for a more thorough introduction to survival analysis. In Figure 4, we compare three different preprocessing methods: (i) whitening, (ii) log normalization, and (iii) YJ, each followed by a PCA dimensionality reduction step. More precisely, whitening (i) consists in centering and reducing to unit variance the total read counts of all genes across all samples, log normalization consists in applying u↦log⁡(1+u)maps-to𝑢1𝑢u\mapsto\log(1+u) to raw read counts before applying global whitening, and YJ is a global YJ transform on the total read counts. We then evaluate each strategy using 5-fold cross-validation with 5 different seeds. We refer to Section E.2 for experimental details. While this experiment is performed in a pooled environment, note that, importantly, each step has a federated pooled-equivalent version: apart from the proposed SecureFedYJ for YJ, see e.g. [21] for PCA, and Webdisco [31] for Cox model fitting. This simplified setting allows us to understand the importance of the Yeo-Johnson transformation in an ideal setting, independently of other potential downstream federated learning artifacts.

In Figure 4, we see that YJ is better or on par with the best method for each cancer: YJ improves prediction results for colorectal cancer, while yielding results which are on par with the best results for lung and pancreas cancers, with a smaller variance.

Synthetic data

We show how applying YJ may help improving performance compared to no or basic preprocessing, and how SecureFedYJ yields improvements compared to local YJ transforms in federated linear regression. To do so, we generate covariates X~~𝑋\widetilde{X} and responses y𝑦y as

X~=(exp⁡(x1),exp⁡(x2+2),σ​(x3))​ with ​X=(x1,x2,x3)∼𝒩​(0,𝐈3),y=βT​X+ε​ with ​ε∼𝒩​(0,0.1),formulae-sequence~𝑋subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥22𝜎subscript𝑥3 with 𝑋subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑥3similar-to𝒩0subscript𝐈3𝑦superscript𝛽𝑇𝑋𝜀 with 𝜀similar-to𝒩00.1\displaystyle\begin{split}\widetilde{X}&=(\exp(x_{1}),\exp(x_{2}+2),\sigma(x_{3}))\text{ with }X=(x_{1},x_{2},x_{3})\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I}_{3}),~\\ y&=\beta^{T}X+\varepsilon\text{ with }\varepsilon\sim\mathcal{N}(0,0.1),\end{split} (6)

where σ​(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot) is the sigmoid function and β=(−1.3,2.4,0.87)𝛽1.32.40.87\beta=(-1.3,2.4,0.87) was randomly chosen. The goal is then to fit a linear model from i.i.d. samples (X~i,yi),i=1,…,nformulae-sequencesubscript~𝑋𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1…𝑛(\widetilde{X}_{i},y_{i}),i=1,\dots,n following (6), after an optional preprocessing step. Similarly to the previous example, we simulate a cross-device FL setting only for the preprocessing steps, and the linear model is then fitted in a pooled setting for simplicity. All the details of the numerical experiments are provided in Section E.3. We suppose that the samples (X~i,yi),i=1,…,nformulae-sequencesubscript~𝑋𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1…𝑛(\widetilde{X}_{i},y_{i}),i=1,\dots,n are homogeneously split across 101010 centers. The responses yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} have a highly nonlinear dependency on the covariates X~isubscript~𝑋𝑖\widetilde{X}_{i}, but depend linearly on the Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}’s (up to Gaussian noise), which are not observed. Hence, we expect that applying a suitable preprocessing step before training a linear model will transform back the X~isubscript~𝑋𝑖\widetilde{X}_{i}’s into the normally-distributed Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}’s and lead to a high performance, compared to no transformation. The results of our experiments are summarized in Figure 5. The left figure shows that the YJ transformation is indeed capable of roughly inverting the X~isubscript~𝑋𝑖\widetilde{X}_{i}’s into the Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}’s, yielding a major improvement compared to no preprocessing or standard centering and reduction to unit variance. Besides, the right figure shows that even in this homogeneous setting where the data is i.i.d. across centers, using a federated version of YJ compared to a local version of YJ leads to better average performance, and reduced variance.

6 Conclusion

Summary of our contributions

In this work, we introduce SecureFedYJ, a method to fit a YJ transformation on data shared by different clients in a cross-silo setting. SecureFedYJ is an SMC version of its pooled equivalent ExpYJ  which builds upon the convexity of the negative log-likelihood of the YJ transformation, a novel result introduced by this work, and on the fact that the sign of its derivative can be computed in a stable way. We show that SecureFedYJ has the same accuracy as a standard YJ transformation on pooled data. In particular, the results do not depend on how the data is split across the clients, making SecureFedYJ resilient to data heterogeneity. Besides, the quantities disclosed by SecureFedYJ during the training to the central server do not leak any other information than what is contained in the final parameters (μ∗,λ∗,σ∗2)subscript𝜇subscript𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝜎2(\mu_{*},\lambda_{*},\sigma^{2}_{*}).

Limitations and future work

While Brent minimization has a super-linear convergence, our approach only has a linear convergence, as it relies on exponential search. This can be an issue if the communication costs between the clients and the server are high. Acceleration could be achieved by either adapting Brent minimization to a cross-silo setting, or applying a second-order method. We leave the development of a faster SMC methods using either of those two approaches to future work.

Another limitation is that even if our approach reveals only information that would be contained in the final fitted parameters, such parameters themselves might leak information about individual samples, as our approach is not differentially private (DP) [16]. By adding Gaussian or Laplacian noise to each sample’s features when computing the Sgsubscript𝑆𝑔S_{g} terms one could, in principle, make the resulting algorithm DP [1]. However it is unclear to what extent the noise would impact the final accuracy of the method.

Finally, we only consider an honest-but-curious setting. We do not explore the threat of a malicious participant that would purposely deviate from the protocol to either gain more information or to jeopardize the convergence. We leave this investigation to future work.

Appendix A Additional properties of the Yeo-Johnson transformation

A.1 Derivation of the Yeo-Johnson log-likelihood

Using the change of variables rule, the probability to draw a set of points {xi}subscript𝑥𝑖\{x_{i}\} such that {Ψ​(λ,xi)}Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖\{\Psi(\lambda,x_{i})\} follows a Gaussian distribution of mean μ𝜇\mu and variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is given by:

ℙ​({xi}|λ,μ,σ)=ℙ​({Ψλ​(λ,xi)}|λ,μ,σ)∗detJ​[{xi},Ψ​(λ,xi)]ℙconditionalsubscript𝑥𝑖𝜆𝜇𝜎ℙconditionalsubscriptΨ𝜆𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆𝜇𝜎𝐽subscript𝑥𝑖Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖\mathbb{P}(\{x_{i}\}|\lambda,\mu,\sigma)=\mathbb{P}(\{\Psi_{\lambda}(\lambda,x_{i})\}|\lambda,\mu,\sigma)*\det J[\{x_{i}\},\Psi(\lambda,x_{i})] (7)

where detJ​[xi,Ψ​(λ,xi)]𝐽subscript𝑥𝑖Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖\det J[x_{i},\Psi(\lambda,x_{i})] is the determinant of the Jacobian matrix J​[{xi},{Ψ​(λ,xi)}]𝐽subscript𝑥𝑖Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖J[\{x_{i}\},\{\Psi(\lambda,x_{i})\}] defined as:

J​[{xi},{Ψ​(λ,xi)}]a​b=∂Ψ​(λ,xa)∂xb𝐽subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖𝑎𝑏Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑎subscript𝑥𝑏J\left[\{x_{i}\},\{\Psi(\lambda,x_{i})\}\right]_{ab}=\frac{\partial\Psi(\lambda,x_{a})}{\partial x_{b}} (8)

This matrix is diagonal and each term of its diagonal can be computed using Eq. (1). For each value of λ𝜆\lambda and xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}, these diagonal terms can be re-written as exp⁡[(λ−1)​sgn⁡(xi)​log⁡(|xi|+1)]𝜆1sgnsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1\exp[(\lambda-1)\operatorname{sgn}(x_{i})\log(|x_{i}|+1)]. The term ℙ​({Ψλ​(λ,xi)}|λ,μ,σ)ℙconditionalsubscriptΨ𝜆𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆𝜇𝜎\mathbb{P}(\{\Psi_{\lambda}(\lambda,x_{i})\}|\lambda,\mu,\sigma) is equal to:

ℙ​({Ψλ​(λ,xi)}|λ,μ,σ)=∏i1σ​2​π​exp⁡[−(xi−μ)22​σ2]ℙconditionalsubscriptΨ𝜆𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆𝜇𝜎subscriptproduct𝑖1𝜎2𝜋superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝜇22superscript𝜎2\mathbb{P}(\{\Psi_{\lambda}(\lambda,x_{i})\}|\lambda,\mu,\sigma)=\prod_{i}\frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\left[-\frac{(x_{i}-\mu)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}\right] (9)

By taking the logarithm of Eq. (7), we obtain the log-likelihood provided in Section 1 and originally derived on [52].

A.2 Relationship with the Box-Cox transformation

The Box-Cox transformation [5] works similarly to the YJ transformation, but only applies to strictly positive data. The Box-Cox transformation is based on a function Φ​(λ,⋅)Φ𝜆⋅\Phi(\lambda,\cdot) parametrized by λ𝜆\lambda and defined for x>0𝑥0x>0 as:

Φ​(λ,x)={xλ−1λ,if ​λ≠0,ln⁡(x),if ​λ=0.Φ𝜆𝑥casessuperscript𝑥𝜆1𝜆if 𝜆0𝑥if 𝜆0\displaystyle\Phi(\lambda,x)=\begin{cases}\frac{x^{\lambda}-1}{\lambda},&\text{if }\lambda\neq 0,\\ \ln(x),&\text{if }\lambda=0.\\ \end{cases} (10)

It is straightforward to check that for any λ∈ℝ𝜆ℝ\lambda\in\mathbb{R} the YJ transformation ΨΨ\Psi and the Box-Cox transformation ΦΦ\Phi are related by the following equations:

Ψ​(λ,x)={Φ​(λ,x+1)if ​x≥0,−Φ​(2−λ,1−x)if ​x<0.Ψ𝜆𝑥casesΦ𝜆𝑥1if 𝑥0Φ2𝜆1𝑥if 𝑥0\Psi(\lambda,x)=\begin{cases}\Phi(\lambda,x+1)&\text{if }x\geq 0,\\ -\Phi(2-\lambda,1-x)&\text{if }x<0.\end{cases} (11)

A.3 Analytical formulae for the derivatives of the Yeo-Johnson transformation

The YJ function is infinitely differentiable with respect to both of its variables (x𝑥x and λ𝜆\lambda). Here are its successive derivatives with respect to λ𝜆\lambda:

∂λkΨ​(λ,x)={[(x+1)λ​[ln⁡(x+1)]k−k​∂λk−1Ψ​(λ,x)]/λ,if ​x≥0,λ≠0,ln(x+1)k+1/(k+1),if​x≥0,λ=0,([−x+1]2−λ​[ln⁡(−x+1)]k+k​∂λk−1Ψ​(λ,x))/(2−λ),if ​x<0,λ≠2,(−ln⁡(−x+1))k+1/(k+1),if​x<0,λ=2.\partial_{\lambda}^{k}\Psi(\lambda,x)=\begin{cases}[(x+1)^{\lambda}[\ln(x+1)]^{k}-k\partial_{\lambda}^{k-1}\Psi(\lambda,x)]/\lambda,&\text{if }x\geq 0,\lambda\neq 0,\\ \ln(x+1)^{k+1}/(k+1),&\text{if}x\geq 0,\lambda=0,\\ ([-x+1]^{2-\lambda}[\ln(-x+1)]^{k}+k\partial_{\lambda}^{k-1}\Psi(\lambda,x))/(2-\lambda),&\text{if }x<0,\lambda\neq 2,\\ (-\ln(-x+1))^{k+1}/(k+1),&\text{if}x<0,\lambda=2.\\ \end{cases} (12)

Appendix B Background on exponential search

Exponential search [3] is a method to look for an element in an unbounded sorted array. The idea is to first find bounds on the array such that the element is contained within such bounds, and then perform a classic binary search inside these bounds. Let us consider the task of finding the smallest element ui0subscript𝑢subscript𝑖0u_{i_{0}} greater than a threshold C𝐶C in an unbounded sorted array {ui}i∈ℕ∗subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑖superscriptℕ\{u_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}^{*}}. The exponential search iteratively looks at uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} for i∈{1,2,22,24,…}𝑖12superscript22superscript24…i\in\{1,2,2^{2},2^{4},\dots\} until it finds a imaxsubscript𝑖maxi_{\mathrm{max}} such that uimax≥Csubscript𝑢subscript𝑖max𝐶u_{i_{\mathrm{max}}}\geq C. This takes log2⁡(imax)subscript2subscript𝑖max\log_{2}(i_{\mathrm{max}}) steps. Then it performs a binary search between i=imax/2𝑖subscript𝑖max2i=i_{\mathrm{max}}/2 and i=imax𝑖subscript𝑖maxi=i_{\mathrm{max}}, which also takes log2⁡(imax/2)subscript2subscript𝑖max2\log_{2}(i_{\mathrm{max}}/2) steps.

If f​(s)𝑓𝑠f(s) is a strictly increasing function of s𝑠s taking both positive and negative values, one can adapt the exponential search to find the root s0subscript𝑠0s_{0} of f𝑓f. The first step is to find an upper and a lower bound of s0subscript𝑠0s_{0} by evaluating f𝑓f at different points using an exponential grid (e.g. evaluating f𝑓f in s=1,−1,2,−2,22,−22,24,−24,…𝑠1122superscript22superscript22superscript24superscript24…s=1,-1,2,-2,2^{2},-2^{2},2^{4},-2^{4},\dots). Once such bounds are found, one can perform a dichotomic search inside these bounds to find the root s0subscript𝑠0s_{0} of f𝑓f. This dichotomic search has a linear convergence of order 222, with each step summarized in Algorithm 2. It is important to note that this algorithm is correct even if f𝑓f is not increasing, as long as f​(s)<0𝑓𝑠0f(s)<0 when s<s0𝑠subscript𝑠0s<s_{0} and f​(s)>0𝑓𝑠0f(s)>0 when s>s0𝑠subscript𝑠0s>s_{0}, as is the case in this work when f𝑓f is the derivative of the negative YJ log-likelihood.

Figure 6 is an illustration of ExpYJ that is based on exponential search.

A natural extension of the exponential search is to replace the binary search into a k𝑘k-ary search during the dichotomic search. In that case, k−1𝑘1k-1 values of f𝑓f are computed at each round. Such a modification reduces the number of steps required for a given accuracy while increasing the number of operations performed at each step.

Appendix C Proof of Proposition 3.1

We first introduce some lemmas that will be required for the main proof.

Lemma C.1.

Let λ↦fi​(λ)maps-to𝜆subscript𝑓𝑖𝜆\lambda\mapsto f_{i}(\lambda), i=1,…,I𝑖1…𝐼i=1,\dots,I be positive and twice differentiable functions, such that for all i𝑖i, λ↦ln⁡[fi​(λ)]maps-to𝜆subscript𝑓𝑖𝜆\lambda\mapsto\ln[f_{i}(\lambda)] is convex. Then λ↦ln⁡[∑ifi​(λ)]maps-to𝜆subscript𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝜆\lambda\mapsto\ln[\sum_{i}f_{i}(\lambda)] is also convex.

C.1 Proof of Proposition 3.1

Proof.

We start by proving the only shows the convexity of −log⁡ℒYJ​(λ)subscriptℒYJ𝜆-\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}(\lambda), and prove strict convexity in Section C.4.

Let {xi}i=1​⋯​nsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1⋯𝑛\{x_{i}\}_{i=1\cdots n} be our data points and let us split this dataset into non-negative values {xi+}={xi|xi≥0}subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖conditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖0\{x^{+}_{i}\}=\{x_{i}|x_{i}\geq 0\} and negative values {xi−}={xi|xi<0}subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖conditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖0\{x^{-}_{i}\}=\{x_{i}|x_{i}<0\}. Let γi=Ψ​(λ,xi)subscript𝛾𝑖Ψ𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖\gamma_{i}=\Psi(\lambda,x_{i}), αi=Ψ​(λ,xi+)subscript𝛼𝑖Ψ𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖\alpha_{i}=\Psi(\lambda,x_{i}^{+}), and βi=Ψ​(λ,xi−)subscript𝛽𝑖Ψ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖\beta_{i}=\Psi(\lambda,x^{-}_{i}). We denote nα,nβ,nγsubscript𝑛𝛼subscript𝑛𝛽subscript𝑛𝛾n_{\alpha},n_{\beta},n_{\gamma} the lengths of the sets {αi}subscript𝛼𝑖\{\alpha_{i}\}, {βi}subscript𝛽𝑖\{\beta_{i}\} and {γi}subscript𝛾𝑖\{\gamma_{i}\}. For clarity, let us consider the case where both {xi+}superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖\{x_{i}^{+}\} and {xi−}superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖\{x_{i}^{-}\} have at least two distinct items and therefore nα≥1subscript𝑛𝛼1n_{\alpha}\geq 1, nβ≥1subscript𝑛𝛽1n_{\beta}\geq 1 and σα2>0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝛼0\sigma^{2}_{\alpha}>0, σβ2>0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝛽0\sigma^{2}_{\beta}>0. We relegate to Section C.3 the other edge cases. According to Lemma C.3, the expression of negative log-likelihood of the YJ transformation provided in Eq. (3) can be reformulated as:

−log⁡ℒYJ​(λ)=subscriptℒYJ𝜆absent\displaystyle-\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}(\lambda)= n2​log⁡(2​π)−(λ−1)​∑i=1nsign​(xi)​log⁡(|xi|+1)𝑛22𝜋𝜆1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛signsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1\displaystyle\frac{n}{2}\log(2\pi)-(\lambda-1)\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathrm{sign}(x_{i})\log(|x_{i}|+1)
+ln⁡(nαnγ​σα2+nβnγ​σβ2+nα​nβnγ2​(α¯−β¯)2).subscript𝑛𝛼subscript𝑛𝛾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛼2subscript𝑛𝛽subscript𝑛𝛾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2subscript𝑛𝛼subscript𝑛𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑛𝛾2superscript¯𝛼¯𝛽2\displaystyle+\ln\left(\frac{n_{\alpha}}{n_{\gamma}}\sigma_{\alpha}^{2}+\frac{n_{\beta}}{n_{\gamma}}\sigma_{\beta}^{2}+\frac{n_{\alpha}n_{\beta}}{n_{\gamma}^{2}}(\bar{\alpha}-\bar{\beta})^{2}\right). (17)

The first term is constant and the second one is linear in λ𝜆\lambda so we only have to prove the convexity of the last term to prove that the full negative log-likelihood is convex. Using Lemma C.1, we only need to show that λ↦ln⁡(nαnγ​σα2)maps-to𝜆subscript𝑛𝛼subscript𝑛𝛾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛼2\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(\frac{n_{\alpha}}{n_{\gamma}}\sigma_{\alpha}^{2}\right), λ↦ln⁡(nβnγ​σβ2)maps-to𝜆subscript𝑛𝛽subscript𝑛𝛾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(\frac{n_{\beta}}{n_{\gamma}}\sigma_{\beta}^{2}\right) and λ↦ln⁡(nα​nβnγ2​(α¯−β¯)2)maps-to𝜆subscript𝑛𝛼subscript𝑛𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑛𝛾2superscript¯𝛼¯𝛽2\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(\frac{n_{\alpha}n_{\beta}}{n_{\gamma}^{2}}(\bar{\alpha}-\bar{\beta})^{2}\right) are convex. We can get rid of the constant factor and show that λ↦ln⁡(σα2)maps-to𝜆superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛼2\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(\sigma_{\alpha}^{2}\right), λ↦ln⁡(σβ2)maps-to𝜆superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{2}\right) and λ↦ln⁡((α¯−β¯)2)maps-to𝜆superscript¯𝛼¯𝛽2\lambda\mapsto\ln\left((\bar{\alpha}-\bar{\beta})^{2}\right) are convex.

The key idea of the proof is to use the fact that, according to [26], for any set of positive real numbers {ai}subscript𝑎𝑖\{a_{i}\}, λ↦lnσ[Φ(λ,{ai}]\lambda\mapsto\ln\sigma[\Phi(\lambda,\{a_{i}\}] is convex, where Φ​(λ,⋅)Φ𝜆⋅\Phi(\lambda,\cdot) denotes the Box-Cox transformation. Besides we have (see Section A.2):

αi=Ψ​(λ,xi+)subscript𝛼𝑖Ψ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle\alpha_{i}=\Psi(\lambda,x^{+}_{i}) =Φ​(λ,xi++1),absentΦ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖1\displaystyle=\Phi(\lambda,x^{+}_{i}+1), (18)
βi=Ψ​(λ,xi−)subscript𝛽𝑖Ψ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle\beta_{i}=\Psi(\lambda,x^{-}_{i}) =−Φ​(2−λ,1−xi−).absentΦ2𝜆1subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle=-\Phi(2-\lambda,1-x^{-}_{i}). (19)

Therefore lnσ[αi]=lnσ[Φ(λ,(xi++1)]\ln\sigma[\alpha_{i}]=\ln\sigma[\Phi(\lambda,(x^{+}_{i}+1)] which is a convex function of λ𝜆\lambda. Similarly, σ​[{−Φ​(2−λ,1−xi−)}]2=σ​[{Φ​(2−λ,1−xi−)}]2𝜎superscriptdelimited-[]Φ2𝜆1subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖2𝜎superscriptdelimited-[]Φ2𝜆1subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖2\sigma[\{-\Phi(2-\lambda,1-x^{-}_{i})\}]^{2}=\sigma[\{\Phi(2-\lambda,1-x^{-}_{i})\}]^{2}. The function λ↦σ​[{Φ​(2−λ,1−xi−)}]2maps-to𝜆𝜎superscriptdelimited-[]Φ2𝜆1subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖2\lambda\mapsto\sigma[\{\Phi(2-\lambda,1-x^{-}_{i})\}]^{2} is convex as the composition of the linear function λ↦2−λmaps-to𝜆2𝜆\lambda\mapsto 2-\lambda with the convex function λ↦σ​[{Φ​(λ,1−xi−)}]2maps-to𝜆𝜎superscriptdelimited-[]Φ𝜆1subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖2\lambda\mapsto\sigma[\{\Phi(\lambda,1-x^{-}_{i})\}]^{2}.

Let us finally prove the convexity of λ↦ln⁡[(α¯−β¯)2]maps-to𝜆superscript¯𝛼¯𝛽2\lambda\mapsto\ln\left[(\bar{\alpha}-\bar{\beta})^{2}\right]. We recall that α¯>0¯𝛼0\bar{\alpha}>0 and β¯<0¯𝛽0\bar{\beta}<0 and that ln⁡[(α¯−β¯)2]=2​ln⁡[α¯−β¯]superscript¯𝛼¯𝛽22¯𝛼¯𝛽\ln\left[(\bar{\alpha}-\bar{\beta})^{2}\right]=2\ln\left[\bar{\alpha}-\bar{\beta}\right]. Using Lemma C.1, we only need to prove that λ↦ln⁡(α¯)maps-to𝜆¯𝛼\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(\bar{\alpha}\right) and λ↦ln⁡(−β¯)maps-to𝜆¯𝛽\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(-\bar{\beta}\right) are convex. As α¯¯𝛼\bar{\alpha} and β¯¯𝛽\bar{\beta} are defined as sums, still using Lemma C.1, we only need to prove that λ↦ln⁡(Ψ​(λ,xi+))maps-to𝜆Ψ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(\Psi(\lambda,x^{+}_{i})\right) and λ↦ln⁡(−Ψ​(λ,xi−))maps-to𝜆Ψ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(-\Psi(\lambda,x^{-}_{i})\right) are convex for any i𝑖i. Using, Eqs. (18) and (19), it is sufficient to prove that for any real number a≥1𝑎1a\geq 1, the function λ↦ln[Φ(λ,(a)]=ln[(aλ−1)/λ]\lambda\mapsto\ln[\Phi(\lambda,(a)]=\ln[(a^{\lambda}-1)/\lambda] is convex, which is proved in Section C.2.

∎

C.2 Proof that λ↦ln[Φ(λ,(a)]\lambda\mapsto\ln[\Phi(\lambda,(a)] is convex

Let a≥1𝑎1a\geq 1 u​(λ)=(aλ−1)/λ𝑢𝜆superscript𝑎𝜆1𝜆u(\lambda)=(a^{\lambda}-1)/\lambda and g​(λ)=ln⁡u​(λ)𝑔𝜆𝑢𝜆g(\lambda)=\ln u(\lambda). For λ≠0𝜆0\lambda\neq 0, the second derivative of g𝑔g is positive if and only if D=defλ4​(u​u′′−(u′)2)≥0superscriptdef𝐷superscript𝜆4𝑢superscript𝑢′′superscriptsuperscript𝑢′20D\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\lambda^{4}(uu^{\prime\prime}-(u^{\prime})^{2})\geq 0.

We have

D(a,λ)=a2​λ−aλλ2log(a)2−2aλ+1.D(a,\lambda)=a^{2\lambda}-a^{\lambda}\lambda^{2}\log(a)^{2}-2a^{\lambda}+1.

Let us show that D≥0𝐷0D\geq 0 when λ≠0𝜆0\lambda\neq 0. D​(a=1,λ)=0𝐷𝑎1𝜆0D(a=1,\lambda)=0, so we just need to show that ∂aD​(a,λ)>0subscript𝑎𝐷𝑎𝜆0\partial_{a}D(a,\lambda)>0 when a>0𝑎0a>0. As

∂aD(a,λ)=a(λ−1)λ(2aλ−λ2log(a)2−2λlog(a)−2),\partial_{a}D(a,\lambda)=a^{(\lambda-1)}\lambda(2a^{\lambda}-\lambda^{2}\log(a)^{2}-2\lambda\log(a)-2),

let us define T​(a,λ)𝑇𝑎𝜆T(a,\lambda) as:

T(a,λ)=(2aλ−λ2log(a)2−2λlog(a)−2).T(a,\lambda)=(2a^{\lambda}-\lambda^{2}\log(a)^{2}-2\lambda\log(a)-2).

We just need to show that T​(a,λ)>0𝑇𝑎𝜆0T(a,\lambda)>0 when λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 and T​(a,λ)<0𝑇𝑎𝜆0T(a,\lambda)<0 when λ<0𝜆0\lambda<0. As T​(a,0)=0𝑇𝑎00T(a,0)=0, we just need to show that ∂λT​(a,λ)>0subscript𝜆𝑇𝑎𝜆0\partial_{\lambda}T(a,\lambda)>0 when λ≠0𝜆0\lambda\neq 0.

∂λT​(a,λ)=2​(aλ−λ​log⁡(a)−1)​log⁡(a).subscript𝜆𝑇𝑎𝜆2superscript𝑎𝜆𝜆𝑎1𝑎\partial_{\lambda}T(a,\lambda)=2(a^{\lambda}-\lambda\log(a)-1)\log(a).

As a>1𝑎1a>1, log⁡(a)>0𝑎0\log(a)>0, so we just need to show that (aλ−λ​log⁡(a)−1)>0superscript𝑎𝜆𝜆𝑎10(a^{\lambda}-\lambda\log(a)-1)>0 which can be done by replacing x𝑥x by λ​log⁡(a)𝜆𝑎\lambda\log(a) in the following inequality: exp⁡(x)>x+1𝑥𝑥1\exp(x)>x+1 for x>0𝑥0x>0.

To conclude, when λ≠0𝜆0\lambda\neq 0 and a≥1𝑎1a\geq 1, D​(λ,a)≥0𝐷𝜆𝑎0D(\lambda,a)\geq 0, and if a>1𝑎1a>1 then D​(λ,a)>0𝐷𝜆𝑎0D(\lambda,a)>0. Therefore, the second derivative of g𝑔g is positive for any λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0. Using continuity, we can conclude that the second derivative of g𝑔g is positive for any λ𝜆\lambda and that λ↦ln[Φ(λ,(a)]\lambda\mapsto\ln[\Phi(\lambda,(a)] is convex.

Note that if a>1𝑎1a>1, then D>0𝐷0D>0 and we can conclude that λ↦ln[Φ(λ,(a)]\lambda\mapsto\ln[\Phi(\lambda,(a)] is strictly convex.

C.3 Edge cases not covered by the main proof of Proposition 3.1

In the main proof we assume that nα≥2subscript𝑛𝛼2n_{\alpha}\geq 2, nβ≥2subscript𝑛𝛽2n_{\beta}\geq 2 and that σα2>0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝛼0\sigma^{2}_{\alpha}>0, σβ2>0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝛽0\sigma^{2}_{\beta}>0. Said otherwise, we assume that both {xi+}superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖\{x_{i}^{+}\} and {xi−}superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖\{x_{i}^{-}\} have at least two distinct elements. The proof is almost unchanged if this is not the case, as we can discard any term inside the logarithm of Eq. 17. For example, let’s assume that nα=1subscript𝑛𝛼1n_{\alpha}=1. Therefore σα2=0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝛼0\sigma^{2}_{\alpha}=0. We can then rewrite Eq. 17 as:

−log⁡ℒYJ=subscriptℒYJabsent\displaystyle-\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}= n2​log⁡(2​π)−(λ−1)​∑i=1nsign​(xi)​log⁡(|xi|+1)𝑛22𝜋𝜆1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛signsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1\displaystyle\frac{n}{2}\log(2\pi)-(\lambda-1)\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathrm{sign}(x_{i})\log(|x_{i}|+1)
+ln⁡(nβnγ​σβ2+nα​nβnγ2​(α¯−β¯)2).subscript𝑛𝛽subscript𝑛𝛾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2subscript𝑛𝛼subscript𝑛𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑛𝛾2superscript¯𝛼¯𝛽2\displaystyle+\ln\left(\frac{n_{\beta}}{n_{\gamma}}\sigma_{\beta}^{2}+\frac{n_{\alpha}n_{\beta}}{n_{\gamma}^{2}}(\bar{\alpha}-\bar{\beta})^{2}\right). (20)

We only need to show that λ↦ln⁡(nβnγ​σβ2)maps-to𝜆subscript𝑛𝛽subscript𝑛𝛾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(\frac{n_{\beta}}{n_{\gamma}}\sigma_{\beta}^{2}\right) and λ↦ln⁡(nα​nβnγ2​(α¯−β¯)2)maps-to𝜆subscript𝑛𝛼subscript𝑛𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑛𝛾2superscript¯𝛼¯𝛽2\lambda\mapsto\ln\left(\frac{n_{\alpha}n_{\beta}}{n_{\gamma}^{2}}(\bar{\alpha}-\bar{\beta})^{2}\right) are convex as in the main proof.

Any other edge case can be treated similarly, and the proof holds as soon as {xi}subscript𝑥𝑖\{x_{i}\} has at least two distinct elements.

C.4 Strict convexity of the Yeo-Johnson negative log-likelihood.

To prove the strict convexity of the YJ negative log-likelihood, let us notice that under the hypotheses of Lemma C.1, if at least one function λ↦ln⁡(fi)maps-to𝜆subscript𝑓𝑖\lambda\mapsto\ln(f_{i}) is strictly convex, then λ↦ln⁡[∑ifi​(λ)]maps-to𝜆subscript𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝜆\lambda\mapsto\ln[\sum_{i}f_{i}(\lambda)] is strictly convex. Besides, according to [26], for any set of positive real {ai}subscript𝑎𝑖\{a_{i}\} with at least two distinct elements, λ↦lnσ[Φ(λ,(ai)]\lambda\mapsto\ln\sigma[\Phi(\lambda,(a_{i})] is strictly convex. Therefore, in the case where either {xi+}subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖\{x^{+}_{i}\} or {xi−}subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖\{x^{-}_{i}\} has two distinct elements, we can conclude that the YJ negative log-likelihood is strictly convex.

The only problematic case is when both σα2=0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝛼0\sigma^{2}_{\alpha}=0 and σβ2=0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝛽0\sigma^{2}_{\beta}=0. In that case {xi}subscript𝑥𝑖\{x_{i}\} has only two distinct element: one positive or null and one strictly negative. In that case, λ↦σ​[{Φ​(λ,1−xi−)}]2maps-to𝜆𝜎superscriptdelimited-[]Φ𝜆1subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖2\lambda\mapsto\sigma[\{\Phi(\lambda,1-x^{-}_{i})\}]^{2} is strictly convex as λ↦ln[Φ(λ,(a)]=ln[(aλ−1)/λ]\lambda\mapsto\ln[\Phi(\lambda,(a)]=\ln[(a^{\lambda}-1)/\lambda] is strictly convex for a>1𝑎1a>1.

Appendix D Secure Multi-Party Computation

D.1 Shamir Secret Sharing

Secure Multiparty Computation (SMC) consists in evaluating functions without disclosing their inputs. One way to achieve this result is to use secret sharing. The main idea is that a value hℎh is split into different secret shares hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}, k=1,⋯,K𝑘1⋯𝐾k=1,\cdots,K where K𝐾K is the number of clients. Each client k𝑘k only knows the value of the secret share hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}, and one needs at least p𝑝p shares with 1<p≤K1𝑝𝐾1<p\leq K to recover the initial value hℎh. The set of the secret shares hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} of hℎh is denoted ⟦h⟧delimited-⟦⟧ℎ\llbracket h\rrbracket. Schematically, SMC consists in three main steps: (i) secret sharing, where each client splits its input into secret shares and sends them to the other clients (ii) computation, where the clients perform mathematical computations on the secret shares and obtain secret shares of the output and (iii) reveal steps, where the clients send each other the secret shares of the output in order to reconstruct and reveal the output.

In the Shamir Secret Sharing method [44], the secret shares of hℎh correspond to the values of a given polynomial Ph​(x)subscript𝑃ℎ𝑥P_{h}(x) of order K𝐾K at different points xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} where Ph​(0)=hsubscript𝑃ℎ0ℎP_{h}(0)=h. The values xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} are arbitrarly chosen by the protocol with the constraint that all xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} should be distinct. If all the clients disclose their secret share hk=Ph​(xk)subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑃ℎsubscript𝑥𝑘h_{k}=P_{h}(x_{k}), then the secret hℎh can be recovered by polynomial interpolation. In this framework the addition can be done trivially. If ⟦h⟧={hk}k=1,⋯​K\llbracket h\rrbracket=\{h_{k}\}_{k=1,\cdots K} and ⟦g⟧={gk}k=1,⋯​K\llbracket g\rrbracket=\{g_{k}\}_{k=1,\cdots K} are the shares of g𝑔g, then ⟦g+h⟧={gk+hk}k=1,⋯​K\llbracket g+h\rrbracket=\{g_{k}+h_{k}\}_{k=1,\cdots K} are shares of g+h𝑔ℎg+h. Said otherwise, ⟦g+h⟧=⟦g⟧+⟦h⟧\llbracket g+h\rrbracket=\llbracket g\rrbracket+\llbracket h\rrbracket. Therefore adding two shared secrets requires no communication between the clients. Similarly, multiplying a shared secret by a public constant c𝑐c is done without communication as ⟦cg⟧=c⟦g⟧\llbracket cg\rrbracket=c\llbracket g\rrbracket. However, multiplying two shared secrets, i.e. computing shares of ⟦g​h⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑔ℎ\llbracket gh\rrbracket is more involved and requires one round of communication. More precisely, each client has to send one scalar quantity to all the other clients during this process, as explained for example in [37], section 3.

D.2 Fixed-Point Representation

The secret shares in SMC belong to a finite set ℤpsubscriptℤ𝑝\mathbb{Z}_{p} where p𝑝p is a prime number and all the operations are integer operations done modulo p𝑝p. In practice we consider integers encoded using l𝑙l bits, then we choose the smallest prime number p𝑝p such that 2l<psuperscript2𝑙𝑝2^{l}<p and we perform each operation modulo p𝑝p. Therefore any value has to be encoded as an integer using a finite number of bits. To encode negative integers, we consider that encoded integers between 00 and 2l−1−1superscript2𝑙112^{l-1}-1 are positive and encoded integers between 2l−1superscript2𝑙12^{l-1} and 2l−1superscript2𝑙12^{l}-1 are negative. We have to choose a value of l𝑙l large enough such that the highest absolute value considered is below 2l−1superscript2𝑙12^{l-1}. Real-value numbers are encoded using fixed-point precision, as described in [8], where the f𝑓f least significant bits of the encoding correspond to the decimal part, and the l−f𝑙𝑓l-f most significant bits correspond to the integer part. The addition of two fixed-point numbers in SMC can be done as described in Section D.1. However, multiplying two fixed-point representation numbers in SMC is more complex as the result must be divided by 2fsuperscript2𝑓2^{f}, i.e. the 2fsuperscript2𝑓2^{f} least significant bits are discarded. As explained in detail in [8], multiplying two fixed-point numbers requires two rounds of communication (instead of one round of communication for the multiplication of two integers).

D.3 Comparison in SMC

In SecureFedYJ , we need to compute in SMC the sign of an expression, which is equivalent to making a comparison with 00. As we are using fixed-point representation encoding, computing the sign amounts to computing the most significant bit of the binary decomposition of a given shared secret. In order to do so, we use the method described in [38], which works for any SMC framework supporting addition and multiplication. This method requires 101010 rounds of communication among the clients (666 of which can be done offline, i.e. they correspond to random values exchanged beforehand and can be done regardless of the value of the input). During these 10 rounds of communication, 153​l+423​log⁡l+24153𝑙423𝑙24153l+423\log l+24 multiplications are performed, 135​l+423​log⁡l+16135𝑙423𝑙16135l+423\log l+16 of which can also be done offline. Notice that other SMC primitives could be used, such as the one described in [17] which provides more efficient way to do SMC comparison.

D.4 MPyC

To implement SecureFedYJ we used the python library MPyC [42]. MPyC is based built upon VIFF framework [11] and is based on Shamir Secret Sharing [44]. We refer to [30] for a discussion of the performance of this library for various SMC tasks.

D.5 Further details on Algorithm 3

The pseudo-code provided in Algorithm 3, is a schematic overview of SecureFedYJand relies on the SMC routines described above. For example, the following line of the pseudo-code:

⟦Sφ⟧=∑k⟦Sk,φ⟧\llbracket S_{\varphi}\rrbracket=\sum_{k}\llbracket S_{k,\varphi}\rrbracket (21)

implies that: (i) each client k𝑘k computes Sk,φsubscript𝑆𝑘𝜑S_{k,\varphi}, divide it into secrets and send these share secrets to all the other clients; (ii) Using the SMC routines described in Sections D.1, D.2 and D.4, the clients compute together the share secrets of ⟦Sφ⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑆𝜑\llbracket S_{\varphi}\rrbracket where Sφ=∑kSk,φsubscript𝑆𝜑subscript𝑘subscript𝑆𝑘𝜑S_{\varphi}=\sum_{k}S_{k,\varphi}. After this step in Algorithm 3, the value of Sφsubscript𝑆𝜑S_{\varphi} is therefore shared using share secrets across all the clients. Notice that the server only plays an orchestration roles in this process.

D.6 Complexity of SecureFedYJ 

At each step of the exponential search, we share 6 secrets (the values of Sgsubscript𝑆𝑔S_{g}), perform 10 fixed-point multiplications (including multiplying and dividing by n𝑛n), and one comparison (i.e. computing the sign of ∂λℒYJsubscript𝜆subscriptℒYJ\partial_{\lambda}\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}.

The 6 secrets can be shared in parallel in one round of communication. Some of the multiplications can also be done in parallel, and only 3 successive rounds of multiplications have to be performed, which require 6 rounds of communications. As stated in Section D.3, the comparison requires 10 rounds of communications. Revealing the secret ΔΔ\Delta also requires one round of communication. Notice that the additions do not require any round of communication. This amounts to 181818 communications per exponential search step. Besides, computing ⟦Sϕ⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑆italic-ϕ\llbracket S_{\phi}\rrbracket at the beginning of the algorithm and computing and revealing μ∗subscript𝜇\mu_{*} and σ∗2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}_{*} at the end of the algorithm requires 6 more rounds of communication. Overall, performing 404040 steps of exponential search with SecureFedYJ costs 18×40+6=7261840672618\times 40+6=726 rounds of communications.

For each elementary operation, such as sharing a secret, revealing a secret or making a multiplication, the order of magnitude of the size of the message sent by each client to the other clients is ⌈log2⁡(p)⌉subscript2𝑝\lceil\log_{2}(p)\rceil bits. Notice that log2⁡(p)subscript2𝑝\log_{2}(p) is of the same order of magnitude of l𝑙l as p𝑝p is the smallest prime number above 2lsuperscript2𝑙2^{l}. More precisely, each client sends around l𝑙l bits to each of the other clients for these elementary operations. The overall size of the messages exchanged during the 726 rounds of communications mentioned above is mainly dominated by the 153​l+423​log⁡l+24153𝑙423𝑙24153l+423\log l+24 multiplications done at each of the 40 comparisons. Taking l=100𝑙100l=100, we find that each client sends overall around 6.5 107superscript6.51076.5\ 10^{7} bits (or ∼8similar-toabsent8\sim 8 Mega-bytes) to each of the other clients during SecureFedYJ.

Appendix E Details of the numerical experiments

E.1 Datasets used in this work

Datasets exposed by scikit-learn API used in Figure 2 and Figure 3

For numerical experiments, we use four public datasets available in the UC Irvine Machine Learning repository [15] under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) license and exposed by the scikit-learn datasets API. These datasets are the Iris dataset [18] (150 samples, 4 features), the Wine Data Set (178 samples, 13 features), the Optical Recognition of Handwritten Digits Data Set (1797 samples, 64 features) and the Breast Cancer Wisconsin (Diagnostic) Data Set (569 samples, 30 features). Only keeping features that have at least two distinct values, these datasets provide a total of 108 different features.

Extra UC Irvine Machine Learning repositories used to test Brent minimization method

Genomic data used in Figure 4

For genetic experiments, we rely on RNA-seq expression data from The Cancer Genome Atlas, expressed in Fragments per Kilobase Million (FPKM). We focus on 3 cancers: colorectal cancer (COAD), lung cancer (LUAD + LUSC), and pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PAAD). These datasets are available on https://portal.gdc.cancer.gov/ under Open Access.

E.2 Experiments on TCGA data

Based on FPKM counts, we load all available data for each cancer of interest, removing genes with null expression for all samples.

Pipeline

Our pipeline consists of three steps:

  1. 1.

    Normalization: either whitening, log, or Yeo-Johnson transformation;

  2. 2.

    Dimensionality reduction: a PCA was applied on normalized data to reduce dimension (dimension 128128128 for lung and colorectal cancer, 909090 for pancreatic cancer);

  3. 3.

    Cox Proportional Hazards (CoxPH) [10] model fitting.

Normalization

All normalization steps are performed on counts, regardless of the genes, as counts are related to the same underlying phenomenon induced by next-generation RNA sequencing. In other words, for the plain whitening, a single mean and variance is computed. For log, following application of log(1+⋅)\log(1+\cdot) to all entries, a similar count-level whitening is performed. For the YJ transformation, we perform 101010 iterations of the proposed algorithm.

CoxPH model training

CoxPH models are fitted with lifelines (0.26.4). We use an ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} regularization of magnitude 101010 for each cancer, without any hyperparameter optimization.

Cross-validation

Results are computed following 555-fold stratified group cross-validation, repeated 555 times with different seeds. Stratification is performed to ensure a balanced set of censored patients in each fold, while ensuring that samples belonging to the same patients end up in the same group to avoid over-estimating the generalization of the model.

E.3 Experiment on synthetic data

To generate the results of Figure 5, we sampled for each of the 10 centers 200 datapoints using Eq. (6). We then apply an optional preprocessing steps before fitting a linear regression model using scikit-learn LinearRegression model on the pooled data. Another dataset of 200 points was then generated, and we computed the R2 on this unseen dataset. This experiment was repeated 1000 times using each time a different seed and the box plot in Figure 5 presents the min-max, the median the first and the third quartile. The different preprocessing steps shown are:

  • •

    None: no preprocessing step is applied

  • •

    Whitening: for each of the three dimensions of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}, we subtract the empirical mean and we divide by the empirical standard deviation computed across all ten centers to the train dataset and the test dataset

  • •

    LocalYJ: we use one center randomly chosen to perform ExpYJ with tmax=20subscript𝑡max20t_{\mathrm{max}}=20 to each of the dimensions of the dataset. The fitted triplets λ∗,μ∗,σ∗2subscript𝜆subscript𝜇subscriptsuperscript𝜎2\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma^{2}_{*} found for each column are then used to normalize the dataset of all 10 centers and the test dataset.

  • •

    Federated YJ: We apply SecureFedYJ with tmax=20subscript𝑡max20t_{\mathrm{max}}=20 on the 10 centers to each of the dimensions of the dataset. The fitted triplets λ∗,μ∗,σ∗2subscript𝜆subscript𝜇subscriptsuperscript𝜎2\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma^{2}_{*} found for each column are then used to normalize the dataset of all 10 centers and the test dataset.

E.4 Testing Brent minimization on more dataset

As explained in the paragraph Numerical stability of ExpYJ of Section 3, applying blindly the Brent minimization method of scikit-learn to minimize the Yeo-Johnson negative log-likelihood might result in numerical instabilities and might collapse all the values of the dataset into a single value. To check further whether this phenomenon is likely to appear, we apply the scikit-learn Yeo-Johnson transformation to various real-life tabular datasets of the UC Irvine Machine Learning repository [15] (which are under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International, CC BY 4.0). For each dataset, we only kept the features that have at least two distinct values. We found that for the 484 fetaures out of 24 datasets, this issue arises 5 times, as summarized by Table 1

Appendix F Further details on Proposition 4.1

Proposition 4.1 states that all intermediate quantities of SecureFedYJ can be recovered from its final result λ∗subscript𝜆\lambda_{*}. We provide in Algorithm 4 a way to construct the function ℱℱ\mathcal{F} introduced in Proposition 4.1 that can perform this recovery.

We apply Algorithm 4 on the 108 features used in Figure 3, with a fixed-point precision of f=50𝑓50f=50. We numerically check that the output of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} from Algorithm 4 matches the intermediate quantities revealed by Algorithm 3 up to machine precision.
